sect1.title: XM and XL Toolstacks Differences
sect1.para: The purpose of this chapter is to list all differences between xm and xl command line. xm command option which are no more available with xl command can be replaced by the &libvirt; framework using the virsh command. In this documentation only the first OPTION for virsh will be shown. To get more help on this option just do a:

sect2.title: Notation Conventions
sect2.para: To easily understand the difference between xl and xm commands, we will use the following notation conventions:

entry.para: option changed, the option has some minor change
option exists in xm, but xl doesn't include it
option exists in xl, but xm doesn't include it
Verbose, increase the verbosity of the output
Dry run, do not actually execute the command
Force execution. xl will refuse to run some commands if it detects that xend is also running, this option will force the execution of those commands, even though it is unsafe.

sect2.title: Unchanged Options
sect2.para: List of common options between xl and xm commands:

entry.para: Converts a domain name to a DOMAIN_ID
Converts a DOMAIN_ID to a DOMAIN_NAME
Displays the short help message (i.e. common commands)
Pause a domain. When in a paused state the domain will still consume allocated resources such as memory, but will not be eligible for scheduling by the &xen; hypervisor
Change the domain name of DOMAIN_ID to NEW_DOMAIN_NAME

listitem.para: modify the domain's name in DOMXML

entry.para: Send a Magic System Request to the domain, each type of request is represented by a different letter. It can be used to send SysRq requests to Linux guests, see sysrq.txt in your Linux Kernel sources for more information. It requires PV drivers to be installed in your guest OS
virsh send-keys can send Magic Sys Req only for &kvm;
Attach to domain's VNC server, forking a vncviewer process
Enables the vcpu-count virtual CPUs for the domain in question. Like mem-set, this command can only allocate up to the maximum virtual CPU count configured at boot for the domain
Lists VCPU information for a specific domain. If no domain is specified, VCPU information for all domains will be provided
Pins the VCPU to only run on the specific CPUs. The keyword all can be used to apply the cpus list to all VCPUs in the domain
Reads the Xen message buffer, similar to dmesg on a Linux system. The buffer contains informational, warning, and error messages created during Xen's boot process.
Executes the xentop command, which provides real time monitoring of domains. Xentop is a curses interface, and reasonably self explanatory
Prints the current uptime of the domains running
Send debug keys to &xen;. It is the same as pressing the Xen conswitch (Ctrl-A by default) three times and then pressing "keys".
Moves a domain specified by DOMAIN_ID or DOMAIN into a CPU_POOL
Deactivates a cpu pool. This is possible only if no domain is active in the cpu-pool
Detach a domain's virtual block device. devid may be the symbolic name or the numeric device id given to the device by &dom0;. You will need to run xl block-list to determine that number
Creates a new network device in the domain specified by DOMAIN_ID. network-device describes the device to attach, using the same format as the vif string in the domain config file
Hot-plug a new pass-through pci device to the specified domain. BDF is the PCI Bus/Device/Function of the physical device to pass-throug
List pass-through pci devices for a domain
List tmem pools. If -l is specified, also list tmem stats.
Get information about how much freeable memory (MB) is in-use by tmem
Determine if the FLASK security module is loaded and enforcing its policy
Enable or disable enforcing of the FLASK access controls. The default is permissive and can be changed using the flask_enforcing option on the hypervisor's command line

sect2.title: Removed Options
sect2.remark: aginies 2014/08/05: if possible a solution must be provided for all removed options
sect2.para: List of xm options which are no more available with the XL toolstack and a replacement solution if available.

sect3.title: Domain Management
sect3.para: The list of Domain management removed command and their replacement.

entry.para: Print out the xend log. This log file can be found in /var/log/xend.log
Remove a domain from Xend domain management. The list option shows the domain names
Adds a domain to Xend domain management
Start a Xend managed domain that was added using the xm new command
Dry run - prints the resulting configuration in SXP but does not create the domain
Moves a domain out of the suspended state and back into memory
Suspend a domain to a state file so that it can be later resumed using the resume subcommand. Similar to the save subcommand although the state file may not be specified.

sect3.title: Attach/Detach Devices
sect3.para: All add and detach options are not yet available with XL toolstack. virsh has the attach-device and detach-device options but it doesn't work yet with USB.

entry.para: Print out the xend log. This log file can be found in /var/log/xend.log
Add a new USB physical bus to a domain
Del an USB physical bus from a domain
List all SCSI devices currently attached
Attach a new USB physical bus to domain's virtual port
Detach a USB physical bus from domain's virtual port
List domain's attachment state of all virtual port
List all the assignable usb devices
Create a domain's new virtual USB host controller
Destroy a domain's virtual USB host controller
List all the assignable pci devices

sect3.title: Network Management
sect3.para: vnet has been removed from &xen;. There is no replacement yet for network2-*

entry.para: Create a new version 2 virtual network device
Destroy a domain's version 2 virtual network device
List version 2 virtual network interfaces for a domain

sect3.title: CPU Management
sect3.para: CPU management option has changed. New option are available, see:

entry.para: Adds a CPU pool to Xend CPU pool management
Removes a CPU pool from Xend management

sect3.title: Policy Management
sect3.para: Some policy options has changed, see in the available.

entry.para: Set the policy of the system
Set the policy of the system to the default policy
Get the policy of the system

sect3.title: Label Management
sect3.para: Subcommands interface with &xen; security policy infrastructure has been removed.

entry.para: Remove a security label from domain
Show security label for domain or resource
Show info for each labeled resource

listitem.para: (-) -F=FILE, --config=FILE: Use the given SXP formatted configuration script.
(-) -s, --skipdtd: Skip DTD checking - skips checks on XML before creating.
(+) -t [pv|serial]: Connect to a PV console or connect to an emulated serial console. PV consoles are the only consoles available for PV domains while HVM domains can have both.
(-) -L, --live: Dump core without pausing the domain.
(+) -v, --verbose: Also prints the domain UUIDs, the shutdown reason and security labels.
(*) mem-max domain-id mem: appending t for terabytes, g for gigabytes, m for megabytes,k for kilobytes and b for bytes.
(-) -r, --resource Mbs: Set maximum Mbs allowed for migrating the domain.
(-) --max_iters=MAX_ITERS: Number of iterations before final suspend (default:30).
(-) --max_factor=MAX_FACTOR: Max amount of memory to transfer before final suspend(default: 3*RAM).
(-) --min_remaining=MIN_REMAINING: Number of dirty pages before final suspend (default:50).
(-) --abort_if_busy: Abort migration instead of doing final suspend.
(-) --log_progress: Log progress of migration to xend.log
(+) -e: On the new host, do not wait in the background (on <host>) for the death of the domain.
(+) -C config: Send <config> instead of config file from creation.

sect3.title: Domain management

listitem.para: (+) -c: Leave domain running after creating the snapshot.
(+) -e: Do not wait in the background for the death of the domain on the new host.

sect3.para: (*) trigger DOMAIN <nmi|reset|init|power|sleep|s3resume> VCPU : Only available for HVM domains.

listitem.para: (+) -p CPUPOOL, --cpupool=CPUPOOL: Restrict output to domains in the specified cpupool.
(+) -s, --schedparam: Specify to list or set pool-wide scheduler parameters.
(+) -t TSLICE, --tslice_ms=TSLICE: Timeslice tells the scheduler how long to allow VMs to run before pre-empting.
(+) -r RLIMIT, --ratelimit_us=RLIMIT: Ratelimit attempts to limit the number of schedules per second.

note.title: libvirt status
note.para: virsh only supports credit scheduler, not credit2 scheduler

listitem.para: (+) -f: If -f is specified, xl is going to forcefully remove the device even without guest's collaboration.

sect3.title: Network
sect3.para: (*) network-detach DOMAIN_ID devid|mac: Alternatively the mac address can be used to select the virtual interface to detach.

note.title: now you can use this option:
now you can use this option:
now you can use this option:

entry.para: Update the saved configuration for a running domain. This has no immediate effect but will be applied when the guest is next restarted. This command is useful to ensure that runtime modifications made to the guest will be preserved when the guest is restarted
List count of shared pages.List specifically for that domain. Otherwise, list for all domains
Prints information about guests. This list excludes information about service or auxiliary domains such as &dom0; and stubdoms
Splits up the machine into one cpu-pool per numa node
Insert a cdrom into a guest domain's existing virtial cd drive. The virtual drive must already exist but can be current empty
Eject a cdrom from a guest's virtual cd drive. Only works with HVM domains

List all the assignable PCI devices. These are devices in the system which are configured to be available for passthrough and are bound to a suitable PCI backend driver in &dom0; rather than a real driver
Make the device at PCI Bus/Device/Function BDF assignable to guests. This will bind the device to the pciback driver.
Make the device at PCI Bus/Device/Function BDF assignable to guests. This will at least unbind the device from pciback.

Load FLASK policy from the given policy file. The initial policy is provided to the hypervisor as a multiboot module; this command allows runtime updates to the policy. Loading new security policy will reset runtime changes to device labels
